nodes.name: The top team at FTX made poor decisions
It's fun to be part of a global community of people trying to help the world
There should be a clear way to express that you are concerned about fraud/ sexual harassment in EA spaces/organisations and a thing to do if not listened to
There should be a community-elected board in EA
There should be prediction markets on top EA figures and whether they will be found guilty of scandals
Democratization is a means to an end not an end in itself
I had concerns about crypto
I feel grossed out by what happened at FTX
I thought someone was checking if FTX was legit
EA should not aim to be a community
EAGs should have more robust questioning of key community figures
There should be a financial investigation team of at least 1 person to vet billionaires
We took SBF's money, we didn't have to invest in him reputationally as well
Some members of EA knew SBF had acted dishonestly in the past. It's bad that this information didn't flow to those who needed it
We shouldn't blame ourselves for not spotting fraud faster than billions of dollars of crypto money
People in EA knew the EAs in FTX. We are partially to blame for FTX not being found out sooner
This has been a hard week
EAs should be more wary of utilitarianism as a result.
Others would call me an EA
I work in an EA cause area
I think Longtermism is true
I think Longtermism is less important than just reducing x-risk
Most of the responses people are suggesting are things they thought anyway that have nothing to do with FTX
High trust communities should act very harshly when they catch deception
Lantern lost money in the FTX collapse, so even though they didn't like Sam they probably didn't suspect outright fraud.
ETG through a crypto exchange should've rung alarm bells to begin with
Daytime at EAGs should be a place for meetings, not flirting, however well intentioned.
"EA should democratise", without any detail on how this could happen or would have prevented FTX, is just an applause light.
What SBF did was wrong regardless of how likely it was to succeed.
I feel sad about how much recent criticism has taken the form of attacks on individuals.
SBF's utility should not have been linear - $10Bn for x-risk reduction is better than 50% $20Bn or $50% 0.
The FTX top team did not consider the downside risk of their actions on EA. These harms should have been in their calculations.
It sucks that something I care about is now tainted with harm to FTX depositors.
I am strongly considering giving my grant back, or intend to.
Most reactions at this point are overreactions and we should take a month or two to look back before we make significant changes.
If most members of EA would think your action was wrong if they knew about it, then if it's $100m or more, don't do it.
EA leaders should be transparent about what they knew about SBF and when
EA leaders should be transparent about what they knew about SBF and when - but it's okay if this takes a few months
EA is being criticised more than usual right now even about topics that are totally unrelated to FTX
EA could benefit from more diversity and epistemological humility.
Flirting at EAGs should be heavily discouraged even after daytime.
EAGs should not have raves.
EA orgs should be transparent about who makes important decisions and how
"EA leaders" are the people who control the money and the brand
Distribution of money in EA should be controlled by a much broader group than it is now
People have been building up frustrations and are now airing them
Democratic and transparent processes of decision making are better for both quality and oversight
I think EA is epistemically humble but external people don't seem to think so
EA "leadership" needs to do a better job managing and disclosing potential conflicts of interest.
Key organizations in EA need better safeguards to prevent their viewpoints and leadership activities from being compromised by a megadonor.
Will MacAskill should expand on his statement, not commenting on FTX due to legal exposure, but on his role in SBF rep. laundering prior to
I feel that the long term future is worth caring about, regardless of whether some longtermism™️ is true®️
There needs to be an organization or voice within EA that is financially and otherwise independent of any megadonors.
CEA should publish an annual bubble size/influence map of power players within greater EA and which orgs/what size funds do they influence
CEA should annually publish salaries & extras of everyone within the EA ecosystem, CEA employees, organisers, local EAs, conf "volunteers" etc
Donor-led EA massively undervalues direct constructive action without money, such as food not bombs
It seems likely that most of the value in effective altruism is communicating to existing billionaires how to not be a billionaire better
The actual loss to EA cause areas is not that great. The supposed $16bn of FTX money was never ours and probably didn't even exist.
CEA should list the donors, amounts and where exactly their particular money flows in great amount of digestible graphic detail
Public and media commentary on EA overemphasises utilitarianism.
There should be quality control and challenging content selection at EAG/x to prevent timewasting on half-baked self-promoting ideas
Individuals and orgs may be at fault but it makes little sense to assign blame to the entire community/movement.
There are tractable approaches to improving whistleblower systems in EA
It's all well and good to ask for less harassment, but how to implement it?
There should be a single website with all EA grants, searchable.
Neither FTXFF nor OpenPhil have evidence of being captured by their donors.
The community part of EA is valuable but often not cost effective or charitable (professional orgs or clubs?). It should be more separated
Less harassment is implemented by “culture”; culture norms spread by influential/high rep ppl visibly reinforcing good behaviours.
It was a mistake for FTX to get so involved in partisan politics
It is important to be vegetarian/vegan.
Neartermism is important.
Longtermist causes are orders of magnitude more important than neartermist causes.
I think climate change is an important EA cause area.
I have a high level of trust in EA leadership, broadly construed.
I find the philosophy of longtermism compelling.
I feel comfortable criticising EA leadership publicly.
I had no idea that SBF had a $40 mil penthouse in the Bahamas.
The people who attend EAGs are representative of the broader community.
CEA should make public its admission criteria for EAGs.
I don't believe in longtermism and I don't feel like I can mention that to other EAs.
Many EAs take no significant, costly action, like donating 10% of their income.
It was bad that there wasn't a way to gather information about FTX and people's concerns.
It was a mistake at the time for FTX to be involved in politics
EA organizations should be at least as transparent as governments, subject to disclosed exceptions for compelling reasons.
I identify myself as in full-time EA-related work.
People working in fun jobs at EA organisations is a lesser sacrifice than giving 10% of income
I derive a significant (to me) amount of my income from meta EA organizations or work (not direct work on AI, poverty, etc.)
I think my personal financial contributions are a sizable portion of my overall contribution to the EA movement.
I am dissatisfied or disagree with the political strategy SBF and SBF's orbit pursued
"Be cause neutral" means "do the best thing regardless of your favourite cause", not "split effort evenly between causes people like"
I am dissatisfied or disagree with Protect Our Future PAC's political giving. (the org that did most of SBF's giving in political races).
Consequentialism implies you should be the sort of person that would be best for the world, not calculate the EV of each individual action
I was concerned that SBF's political giving was led by his brother's friend but felt that I could not voice my concern to any relevant EAs.
Will MacAskill has received more hate from the EA community in the last week than Sam Bankman-Fried. That seems unfair.
Stories from "ordinary EAs" should be articulated and shared, so ppl have wider understanding of the community.
There's only so many times you can claim you're afraid of being silenced in an interview in a major newspaper without losing credibility
It's really upsetting to see people hating on poly people because of FTX rumours
It's really upsetting to see people hating on neurodivergent people because of FTX rumours
I am or know someone who needs stims to manage ADHD, and would rather not see overblown claims about them turning SBF into a degen gambler
I noticed that 'dying with dignity' was mostly about consequentialism, bounded rationality, and the unilateralist's curse, not AI risk.
We know too little about the future to be effective longtermists, because of that, longtermist research is often unaccountable.
The lack of diversity in people's educational and occupational background in the EA Community is a red flag.
Sexual harassment is bad and preventing it is important for our community, but I'm confused about what it has to do with FTX
I consider myself to be extremely invested in EA or the EA community; it is a major focus of my life.
It's frustrating how much criticism of EA gets labelled "bad faith". A community trying to improve the world needs to understand it better
The reasons to believe EA leaders didn't deserve the celebration they get predates FTX - FTX just highlights it more
The EA community needs to understand how to interact with the world outside it better. A tight knit community can easily become insular
Will MacAskill should stop being the face of EA. EA shouldn't have a single public face.
Longtermism is mostly a motte and bailey. Motte = future people matter, bailey = AI might kill us in 2-3 decades. This is dishonest
CEA isn't good enough at leadership to play the central controlling role in the community it tries to play
A crisis is also an opportunity. This is a good time to consider what the good and bad in EA is.
I've lost faith in the EA community's ability to live up to its high aspirations. The people are good but systemic issues are neglected
Sam Bankman-Fried looks like he's dark triad - Machiavellian, psychopathy, narcissism. He was never driven by empathy or maximizing utility
This (Polis) is a useful tool: useful for highlighting perspectives and clusters, not representativeness
How EA comes off in news articles is relatively unimportant - good EA work will eventually speak for itself.
It's really bad that EAs don't feel comfortable questioning longtermism. This points to deeper groupthink inside EA.
EA systematically neglects its risks and negative effects based on the false assumption that good intentions, smarts and community are enough
If anyone is at fault it is a few EA community leaders who knew about the SBF issue and not the Global EA community who didn't know anything
The poll suggests that there are two different subgroups within EA: "democratic" and "technocratic". Perhaps EA should split to reflect this
EA could benefit by consulting a wider range of outside experts in areas like politics, org governance, sexual assault, vetting megafunders
I feel less connected to EA in light of the FTX situation.
EA was better before it went in the longtermist direction.
It would have been worse if FTX continued for years stealing and fraudulently funding EA causes before collapsing
We shouldn't beat ourselves up for not finding out FTX sooner but we should take steps to better investigate future concerns & megafunders
EA underappreciates/neglects the impactfulness of the government of the United States--the world's superpower
Sam Bankman Fried used EA to whitewash his reputation and business
Too many of these statements assert "A and B", when I agree with A or B but not both.
The lack of contingency planning for FTX's collapse was a bigger mistake than the failure to anticipate it with higher probability
My degree or career is in STEM
Making clusters explicit using polis will promote tribalism without any benefit
The current fiasco might have been prevented if EA emphasized moral pluralism more
Longtermism and global health would be better off as separate communities
More emphasis on criticism/red teaming could've prevented the current fiasco
Anonymous prediction markets on relevant topics (FTX failure say, or broad reputation crisis risk) could've prevented the current fiasco
The EA community would be stronger if we showed more warmth and appreciation to each other (leadership to members, & members to leadership)
It's a good thing if people are more comfortable criticizing EA in the wake of this, even if most critiques aren't FTX-relevant
EA needs to understand the psychology behind what SBF/Caroline/Nishad did, in order to develop safeguards against it
It would be good for EA if Caroline or Nishad explained what went wrong, even if they get more jail time due to speaking publicly
EA was not the primary contributor to the FTX fiasco
We should be more concerned about how effective a governance method is than how democratic it is
Top EAs should be encouraged to take more vacations and get less attached to their work, in order to see a broader perspective
Criticizing EA, or the work of people in it, is bad for your EA career
EA got duped by SBF because of wishful thinking
Even with agree/disagree voting, the EA Forum voting system encourages conformity too much
I self-censor regularly in discussions with EAs
EA leadership should engage carefully with the media instead of letting negative articles get written with no EA input
We should consider abandoning our moral intuitions if a mathematical argument suggests the intuition is incoherent
We should try & identify every point at which the FTX fiasco could've been stopped, and implement new safeguards for as many as possible
If EA deferred to mainstream opinion more, it would lose something valuable
When answering a pol.is statement, it can be hard to consider the claim in isolation on its merits, without confusing it for related claims
The FTX fiasco is the worst thing that ever happened to EA
We should be concerned that broad popularization of longtermism could be used to justify actions that are actually harmful on expectation
It is easy to suggest safeguards but safeguards have costs as well as benefits. These need to be considered.
EA should rerun the criticism contest at least every 5 years
Even if EA couldn't have caught SBF's fraud, there are other important lessons we can take away here
The FTX fiasco is a single data point; we shouldn't update overmuch
Criticism & transparency are complementary goods--criticism is of little use without transparency to know what to criticize, and vice versa
EA underrates risks from poor governance.
A significant harm from transparency is an incentive to look good without actually being good
At least 30% of pol.is statements should have a number in them, and you agree/disagree based on whether the number is too high or low
EA thought leaders were largely misguided in their turn from near-termist to long-termist priorities
Utilitarianism is the one true normative ethical theory
Consequentialism is the one true family of normative ethical theories
Utilitarianism provides an effective way for humans to calculate the moral rightness or wrongness of their actions
The actions of FTX and SBF provides some meaningful update on the consequences of promoting consequentialism
Enough has been done by the EA community to guide against ends-justifying-means moral reasoning.
More emphasis should be placed in the EA community on rules or virtues to protect against ends-justifying-means moral reasoning.
There should be more engagement with ethical theories besides utilitarianism in the EA community moving forward.
There should be less hero-worship of early or influential people within EA, moving forward.
Virtue ethics is largely useless.
Deontological ethics is largely useless.
There should be more engagement and understanding of moral philosophers outside of Singer and Parfit in the EA community.
I am proud to be called an effective altruist.
I am happy with the level and quality of dialogue on the EA online forum.
Utilitarianism is intuitive to me.
Utilitarianism is unintuitive to me.
EA should improve towards greater diversity in gender and race.
The global EA community is incredibly valuable for people outside of EA hubs
Donors should be a minority on a charity board
It's not that hard to design a democratic structure for the EA movement.
I have no idea about the actual process how the opinions of EA leaders get the status of quasi-official opinions of "the EA community".
I have no idea how some people become "EA leaders" in the first place.
I live in continental Europe.
I have read the reporting by The Economist about the EA / FTX thing.
I have listened to the Sam Harris podcast episode about the EA / FTX thing.
I have listened to the "Ones and Tooze" podcast episode about FTX.
I am younger than 40 years.
I am older than 30 years.
I have a background in economics.
The FTX thing does not tell us much about the relative value of different moral philosophies.
I don't care per se how expensive SBF's real estate was.
The opinions of the "EA leadership" are often not representative of most of the EA community, but are treated as such.
The word "longtermism" is divisive.
I consider myself part of the EA community.
I frequently read posts in the EA forum.
I frequently read Lesswrong.
I consider myself part of the rationalist community.
What is perceived and represented as the opinion of the "EA community" will not be changed by surveys like this one.
What is perceived and represented as the opinion of the "EA community" does not reflect opinions of most EAs.
I think it's somewhat likely I would've acted similarly to SBF if put in a similar situation.
It's actually okay to accept fraudulent money, as long as you don't cover it up or give favors.
The Boards at EA orgs routinely lack the skills and experience you would expect of Board members
Boards of EA orgs would be more effective if they recruited fewer moral philosophers and more people with relevant governance expertise
